habitat_description:
Populations of the flat-headed snake are well established in eastern Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Arkansas, southwestern Illinois, Texas, and central Louisiana. The range also extends into Coahuila and Tamaulipas, Mexico (Conant and Collins 1991; Ernst and Ernst 2003). 

Burrowing has been observed in or using soil, decaying logs, and debris. Considered a semifossorial snake that spends substantial periods of time under logs or rocks after spring or summer rain. Eggs are usually laid in relatively shallow hollows underground, in vegetative litter, or under rocks (Cobb 1990; Natureserve.org). Inhabits cropland, grassland, chaparral, hardwood woodland, mixed woodland, shrubland, wooded hillsides, rocky forest edges, moist deciduous woods, thorn woodland, grass-brushland, shrubland, rocky prairie, pine-oak uplands, and oak-juniper woodland (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Tennant 1998; Trauth et al. 2004; Werler and Dixon 2000).

SE	-Found in association to moist deciduous woods, thorn woodland, pine-oak upland, oak-juniper woods, and various density types of grasses and shrubs.
